prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Underpass Echo

'Twas drizzledown, and concrete coves
Did rumblethrum beneath the span;
All dripplesome the gutter-groves,
And bus-beasts burbled van-by-van.

"Beware the Underpass Echo, child!
The mouths that mock, the calls that catch!
Beware the lamp-drip, tile-beguiled,
And shun the clangy Clatter-snatch!"

He palmed a sprightly jingle-pence;
Long time the clinksome foe he sought—
He lounged beside the pillar-fence
And whistled whirls of echoed thought.

While slumbry-bent, with shoulders bowed,
His sneaker-soles all slick and quick,
Out through the arch the Echo flowed—
A mimic-thing all tickleclick.

Flip-flap! the copper pinged the gloom;
His hollo leapt to twin its track;
From ribbed stone ribs of tunnel-room
Came hollo back, and hollo back.

He knotted up his nimble tongue
And held his breath from front to nape;
The Echo starved for want of sung,
And thinned into the water-scape.

"And hast thou stilled it, sprightly sprout,
The Underpass Echo grim?
O hushsome joy! O muffled shout!
Come home with hush brimful to brim!"

'Twas drizzledown, and concrete coves
Did rumblethrum beneath the span;
All smilch and sleek the gutter-groves—
No mock returned from arch or van.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Mumblemist of Morn

At dim of dawn the slither-fogs
did swurl and snither down the lane;
All drabblesome the dewy bogs,
and hedge-wrens hushed their strain.

Hold fast thy sunspoke, sprightly sprout!
Shun gloamfogs thick with clag and clout;
They nip and numble cheeks about
and muffle morning out.

He shouldered up his dawnspun stave
and tramped the claggy, clotted lea;
Long while he sought the murkling maze,
then perched beside a tree.

While brooding there in thicksome mood,
the Mumblemist, with slurble sigh,
came wimpling through the bramblewood
and paled the world awry.

Snish-snap! went forth the dawnspun stave—
a sun-gleam whicked from tip to toe;
It sliced the grey in gauzy waves
and made the gutters glow.

The Mumblemist unspooled and thinned,
it driftled, drailed, and dwindled wan;
In skeins of silver undisciplined
it lifted, lost, was gone.

O brightsome day! Harray! Hurray!
He glad-loped back by garden stone;
The kettle chimed a honeyed lay,
the teacups blushed and shone.

At morn made clear, no slither-fogs
did swurl or snither down the lane;
All twinkly were the dewy bogs,
and hedge-wrens found their strain.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Déjà Vool

At dopply dusk the miry merves
Did girole, gromble through the lane;
Roundtwist about the twiddle curves,
Thought’s echo rang—and rang again.

Take heed the Déjà Vool, my sprout—
That twindle-eyed with doubled grin!
It loops your footstep in and out
And tugs you where you’ve once-just-been.

He gripped his ring-ed rapier tight,
His memory-net of knotted thread;
He waited in the twillick light
And twice he breathed, and twice he said—

And, as in thunkish dream he stood,
The Déjà Vool, on velvet tread,
Came whisperfling through twinleaf wood—
It came, it came! past once it sped.

He snicked and snerked; the loopblade sung—
Once, twice—the slice rewound the start;
It split the moment, rung by rung,
And stitched and snipped his circling heart.

And filly-fall the Vool lay still,
Unwound from all its swandled loops;
He bore its hush to hollow hill
And skipped in double-dancing whoops.

“Rejoice!” he cried, “my twistling chuck,”
And clapped a clap that clapped anew;
“O rare the turn whose ends unstuck—
O rare, O rare, now new-on-new!”

At dopply dusk the miry merves
Still girole, gromble through the lane;
But when you cross the twiddle curves,
One step goes strange—and then again.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Wantway

'Twas tramble-time, and sneakered folk
Did shuffle-scramble o'er the green;
All tuftish was the meadow-yolk,
And wantways wound between.

"Beware the Straight-and-Narrow, sprout!
The posts that fence, the placards preach!
Beware the prickle-bush about,
And shun the Ranger's reach!"

They laced their scuffly soles up tight—
Long time the mapped paths did they plot;
They paused beside a lamplorn light
And foot-thunk on the spot.

And as they eyed the posted rule,
The wantway whispered thin and low;
It beckoned through the grassly cool—
"Come trample where you go."

One-two! One-two! And through and through,
Past hedge and stake and gravel-sum,
They cleft the corner, cut the queue,
And wore the wantway plumb.

"And hast thou marked the Wantway's birth?"
"O footsome day! Huroo, hurray!"
They galumphed back with giddy mirth,
And trod the trodden way.

'Twas tramble-time; the sneakered folk
Now shuffle-scramble o'er the green:
All tuftless grows the meadow-yolk—
The wantway runs between.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Conferencewocky

It was briefish, and the swivel-chairs
Did whir and whisper round the conference room;
All tensey were the budget snares,
And screenlights cast their gloom.

Take heed the Buzzwordbeast, dear peer!
The Scope-Creep clutches, Deadlines bite!
Avoid the Statuscatch you hear
That pings at close of night.

He gripped his clicker-click in hand;
Long time the Agenda-worm he sought;
He paused beside the ficus stand
And steeped a pot of thought.

And while he steeped his thinkings there,
The Buzzwordbeast with jargon-plea
Came shuffling through the filtered air
And cooed, "Align with me."

Click-click! Flick-flick! the pointer flared,
The slide-lance flashed from tip to tip;
He boxed the scope, un-risked the snare,
And muted every quip.

He felled it flat; with captured deck
He stride-a-strutted back apace;
Mugs clinked a merry metric check,
Joy graphed on every face.

"You’ve tamed the Buzzwordbeast!" they cried,
"O quarterly hurrah—hooray!"
He grinned; across the carpet-tide
The rolling chairs made sway.

It was briefish, and the swivel-chairs
Did purl and purr around the room;
Unknotted were the budget snares;
The minutes lost their gloom.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brangle in the Music Room

At velvet dusk the music room
In hushwood rafters hummed;
The flitterflutes went frindle-froom,
The thrumble-drums were thummed.

Take heed of brangly big-bassoons
That bworple in the gloam;
And mind the sneery piccaloons,
They squeak and skitter home.

A smallling hand, with swizzle-stick,
Stepped brave into the round;
Their candle-eyes went glimmerquick—
They pried the sleeping sound.

They flicked the air—oh swish-a-sway!—
The strumble-strings all sighed;
The pianobird went plink-a-play,
The cymblestars replied.

The metromancer, tick-tock-taught,
Kept steady, stern and kind;
The rabble-notes untanglethought,
And braided into mind.

Then rose a rumble-rain of tune,
A whirl of silver bloom;
It waltzed the lamps, it bowed the moon,
It filled the murmuroom.

And when the lastling echo curled
To nest in velvet eaves,
That childling grinned at music’s world
All dappled in its leaves.
label: low

prompt: Write a poem about map in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cartowocky

By lamplight lay the crackled chart,
All crimp and crinkle, fold and fray;
The snaily streams did squig and dart
Through latitwists of gray.

The compass-rose, with tinsel points,
Span petal-pricks astray;
The humple hills had crumple joints,
And coasts went scallop-sway.

“Beware the Mapperwock, my sprout!
The grid that grips your gaze!
Beware the longitwine! Look out
For rhumb-led, riddled ways!

“Shun latitwists that loop and bind,
Meridiwhirls that snare;
And mind the ‘Here-be’ margin-signed—
For doodled dragons there.”

He took his brass dividers bright,
His plotter keen and quick;
He gripped his inksaw by the bite,
His protract-stick, click-click.

Long time the chartish foe he sought,
By Thither fen and Yon;
He perched upon a margin blot
And counted lines to one—

When, while in scruffish muse he stood,
The Mapperwock drew near—
Through rhumbly grove and merid-wood
It burbled, square-of-sneer.

One swish, two swash—the inksaw sang,
Ker-snick the compass beak!
He snipped the longitwine to fang
And nicked its gridded cheek.

He left it flat; its parchment head
He bundled fold on fold;
He trudgelumped mapward home instead,
Ink-brave and bright and bold.

“And hast thou quelled the Mapperwock?
Come caper, clever sprout!
O vellum-vive! Hurray o’clock!
We’ll fold the terror out.”

By lamplight lies the settled chart,
Less crimp and crinkle, fold and fray;
The roads unknot, the rivers start
And find their proper way.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on layover bay in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Layover Bay

’Twas lag-o’clock; the trolley-tides
Did clinkle-clatter by the quay;
All bleary were the transfer guides,
In windy Layover Bay.

Beware the Cancelkraken, friend—
Those jaws of wait, that clutch of catch!
Beware the Overbumpers, and
The frumious Gate-Switch Snatch!

He gripped his vorpal boarding pass;
Long while the whirligates he sought—
He slumped beneath a charging-mast
And knitted knots of thought.

And as in mufflish muse he sat,
The Delaydelion came,
Wind-whiffling off the tarmac-flat,
And burbling blamey blame.

Beep-boop! Beep-boop! And through and through
The scanner snicker-scanned!
He stamped his step; the queue withdrew;
The pushback tug was manned.

And hast thou slipped the Gatechange-gnash?
Come to our arms, O beamish mate!
O frabjous eve! Callooh! Clash-clash!
They chortled, “Board at Gate!”

’Twas lag-o’clock; the trolley-tides
Now lulled and dozed beside the quay;
All beamish went the boarding lines—
Farewell to Layover Bay.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Burniwonk

Soft-gleam the panes; the pixel-flock
went murmuring through menu-gloom;
The taskbar ticked its tockly-tock,
and applets budded bloom.

"Mind you the Burniwonk," said Gran,
"that ghost that gnaws the steadfast hue;
It brands the bright of static span
and glues the gaze to view.

It sucks the savor from the shade,
it chews the channels ghost-thin;
With afterglyph and logo-lade
it stamps a stuck-in grin."

I took my saver-saber keen,
my dither-shield of sheeny sheen;
I set the shift to roam the screen,
and let the pixlings preen.

Through scrollow vale and toolbar fen
the Burniwonk came creep-a-spin;
Its jaw a jag of navbar-then,
its breath a cidered din.

It corkscrewed out its logo-lash,
with gutter-glare and graven chin;
I raised a wave of wobble-wash
to blur the biting grin.

Ker-klack! the saver-saber spun,
the dithers danced in drifty spin;
I scrolled it, rolled it—blur begun—
and sloughed its stuck-on skin.

"All clear!" sang Gran. "But mind your keep—
let cycles roam and pixels creep;
For idle hours make stains begin,
and burniwonks will seep."

Soft-gleam the panes; the pixel-flock
go driftle-drift through menu-gloom;
The taskbar hums its tickly-clock,
and icons bud and bloom.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about Monte Carlo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Monte-Whirl

At dusky-busk the chandeliers
Threw glimmish beams a-flow;
The silken chips went clink-a-shear
Through starry Monte Carlo.

Beware the Monte-Whirl, my sprout,
Whose ball bites red or no!
Beware the baccaratial Bout,
And slotter-sirens low!

He took his jeton-javelin,
Cuff-starched and tuxedo;
Long while he paced the marbled in
By palms of Monaco.

He perched beside a terrace rail,
In rumin-ruffish slow,
When wheelish winds began to wail—
The Monte-Whirl! Hallo!

Its roulette grin, its ivor eye,
Its spokes in ringy row;
It whirred and purred and sang awry,
“Encore! Encore!”—just so.

Clip-clap! the jeton-javelin
Went knicker-knacker—go!
He fenced the rouge, he foiled the noir,
Then dealt a daring throw.

Down, down the whirly-wager fell
With last faint click-a-low;
He snagged the hush, he stilled the bell,
And bowed, “Allons, bravo.”

O lavish day! O lustral suites!
Champagnish fountains flow!
He capered through the foyers’ beats
And tipped his hat, just so.

At dawnish hour the chandeliers
Grew paler, soft and slow;
The satin chips slept, clear of fears,
In mild-mute Monte Carlo.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Wingberwhirl

’Twas houselight-dim, and velour-wings
Went swush and shimmy in the draught;
The flyline-laths hummed shadow-strings,
And sandbags dreamed aloft.

“Beware the Flubbershade, my crew—
That bunglemouth of gobble-cues!
Bewatch the Lampersnarky-boo,
And shun the Bandersnooze!”

He palmed his gaffer-glitter wrench,
Spike-tape in coil, headset a-click;
He crouched beside the masking bench,
In hushish deckhand nick.

“Standby,” the coms went murmle-soft,
“For scrim and boom and thunder-roll!”
Then through the wings with tangle-loft
Came Flubbershade, whole-swol.

Clip-clack! flip-flap! the flyrails sang;
He called the lights and set the fly;
The gobo-ghosts went prance and pang,
He spiked the snarl awry.

He looped the slack and lashed the slack,
He tamped the trap and tied the throw;
The Flubbershade went flap to black—
Unravelled into show.

“And hast thou tamed the Flubbershade?
Come, crewling, come—bravissimo!”
He bowed in black where shadows braid,
And let the houselights glow.

’Twas houselight-dim; the velour-wings
Now whispren stillness through the draught;
The flyline-laths hum shadow-strings,
And sandbags dream aloft.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about brown butter in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Brown Butterwocky

It bubbled-brim, the buttergold,
Did fizzle-foom upon the flame;
All nutterbright the panlings rolled,
And brownsome specks took caramel-name.

Beware the Burniburn, dear cook!
Beware the bitter-scorch and smoke!
Shun splutterspry from foamy brook,
The spit and snap the skillet spoke!

He seized his whiskerwhirligy;
Long time the melt-quest there he sought;
He watched the foam turn milk-snowy,
And sniffed the toast of browning thought.

And, as he hovered, stovetop-glow,
The Brown Butterwock drew near;
It hummed a hazel, nutter-low,
A toastish song for cookish ear.

Flip-whirl! Stir-turn! The whisk did dance;
He skimmed the specks that twirl and gleam;
Through golden swales and amber trance,
He shepherded the sizzling stream.

O triumphbright! O toastsome bliss!
He sluiced it over noodlenests;
It kissed sage leaves with buttery kiss,
And wooed the dough in cookie chests.

Yet mind the scorchling’s shadow-creep,
Shun bitter-bane and ashy blame;
Keep watchful ward while bubbles sleep,
Then whisk it off the eager flame.

It bubbled-brim, the buttergold,
Now purls at rest from embered heat;
All nutterbright the kitchen-hold,
And brownborn dreams grow caramel-sweet.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crindle-Creep

’Twas drizzle-dim in Drindle Dell,
where flannelwinds went nip and neep;
the mullen-grass began to swell,
for through the roots there oozed the Creep.

“Mind well the Creep, my sprindle child—
the long-along with hushy tread!
It sours the beams and smarms the tiled,
and weighs your hours like noodle lead.

“It softens steel to taffy-strings,
it droops the rafters, bend by bend;
it gnaws the glue of homely things
and pulls the now toward the end.”

I took my twibble-tempered blade,
my tick-tack shield of spring and sproke;
I sought it where the joists had swayed,
among the knurls of wrinkled oak.

And there it dribbled, slow and sly—
a lollop lump of leak and seep;
with velvet-weights behind its eye,
it sighed and lengthened—Creep by creep.

We waltzed a while in viscous air;
I chopped its ooze to flinder-fleck—
but every slice grew long and spare
and slumped again about my neck.

So then I learned the twindle art:
brace beams and cinch the sleep of eaves;
tie knot to knot the trembling heart
and oil the hinge that slowly heaves.

Now drizzle-bright in Drindle Dell,
the rafters hum; the clocks keep keep;
yet under floorboards, hush and swell,
it bides, it bides—the Crindle-Creep.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awl-Whicker

Squin-twilight chimed the tatterhour,
and seamwinds snuffled through the hides;
All stitchly bloomed the cobbler-flower,
as puckerlings took prickle strides.

"Grip-close the awl," old Stitcher crooned,
"that burin-beak, that bristle spark!
It pecks a path where leather-mooned,
and opens day from seamed-up dark.

"Bewink thy thumb, keep nerves in thrall,
and mind the nip of needle bite;
For gentle seems the little awl,
yet pricks the world to set it right."

So palm to haft and thumb to guard,
he held the prinkle-poking tool;
Its pebbled hilt was knurled and hard,
its point a star that kept its cool.

He sought the Rippery Raveled Rift,
where scrap and skelp in shadow stall;
He heard the snick of threadward lift—
the pick-pick rhyme of Awl-of-All.

Click-crick! the riven gap drew near,
loop-kissed by loops in nimble rows;
The rent unteethed its jag of fear,
and hummed itself to pucker prose.

He stitched the dusk to dawning seam,
he laced the hides of hush and din;
The world, once torn, lay glove-precise,
and wore its weather smooth again.

Back home he set the awl to rest,
its beak asleep in oily grain;
And tatterhour, well-mended, blessed
the prick that made it whole again.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Third-Rail Thrum

Gloam-hour glinted; tunnel air
Went shiver-shave through grit and glum;
The sleepers frowned with iron stare,
And all was third-rail thrum.

“Take care, my kit, of humming rail—
That zappy beast of underways!
Its whispers bite, its brightings flail;
Keep clear of crackleblaze.

“Avoid the sizzle-snare and spark,
Step wide of gleam and glimmer-plum;
No boot nor bone withstands the arc—
Mind well the third-rail thrum.”

I donned my rubber-witted greaves,
My baffle-gloves and grounded drum;
With breaker-blade beneath my sleeves,
I sought the third-rail thrum.

Through cable-grove and ballast dell
Where driplets ding and train-lights come,
The tunnel breathed its charcoal spell—
A long, low, third-rail thrum.

Hush-hither slid the Hummerwot:
A shimmerworm of coiling hum;
Its volt-tongue licked, its whiskers shot
A fitful, crackling plumb.

Flip-flash! I flicked the breaker-skein—
Ker-chack! went switch and circuit’s sum;
The darkness gave a soot-black rain,
And hushed the third-rail thrum.

Back home they cried, “O gleesome boon!
Thou clicked the click that saved us some!”
The tunnels dream beneath the moon—
No more the third-rail thrum.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about interference in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Interfere

In scrimble dusk the quiver-quaves
went phaseling o’er the plain;
All hush-and-loud the ripple-knaves,
as nodenodes knit the rain.

They say the Interfere stalks near,
with cancel-clutch and grin;
It muddles notes to notions queer,
and blends the out with in.

I raised my phasebright sabre up—
a steadied, steady spark;
With helm of coherence-cup
I stepped into the dark.

Through swaysome air it shimmer-loomed,
a crosshatch-crested maw;
Its lilt was lost, its thunder-boomed—
two tunes at once I saw.

Crest leaned to crest—oh louder sang
the clamor-crown of wave;
But trough to crest—no echo sprang,
a hushhole wide as grave.

I feinted left with flickle-feet,
then right with klicker-klack;
I sliced between the doubting beat
and split its braided track.

It fell in fluster, phased apart;
the tangles thinned to clear.
The world beat true with single heart—
no crosschurn in the ear.

Now scrimble dusk may quiver-qualm,
yet songs go straight and sheer;
So tune your threads with patient calm
and mind the Interfere.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on umbrella in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bumbershoot and the Drizzlesnark

It was pluvvy, and the dribble-drabs
Went swirl and skimple down the lane;
All mizzle-mad the puddlecrabs,
And soggletuft the pane.

“Beware the Drizzlesnark, my sprout!
Beware the Squallabeast!
Beware the sneeple-sleet without
And wind that gobbles east!”

He primed his bumbershoot in hand—
Its ribspokes clicky-quick;
Long time he sought the dribber land,
Through plash and splutter-thick.

In gruffish thought he puddle-stood
By grumble-gutter seam,
When whoop! from out the gustergloom
A Tempest, lash and scream—

Its thunder-teeth went rummle-rack,
Its eyes were whirligreen;
He popped his brolly—clack-a-clack—
A doming satin sheen.

He tilted, twirled, and over-arched
The batter-battering rain;
The galelets nipped and squallers marched—
They floundered, flapped in vain.

Then swish and swoop and flappa-flap!
He domed the sky askew;
The Tempest, knotted in the cap,
Unraveled into blue.

“O plashy day! Yaroolaroo!”
He bumbled home, unsoaked;
“Come, cuddle-bairn!” the kinfolk cooed,
“The wild wet’s been out-spoked!”

It is pluvvy yet; the dribble-drabs
Go meek and mizzle-tame;
All dapper-dry the puddlecrabs,
And sunwisp rims the frame.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about science fair in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Quibblequark at the Science Fair

It beaker-hour; slicksome tubes
went whorl and wobble there;
The trifold-groves with pasteboard-lobes
made crinkly hush of air.

“Beware the Quibblequark, my sprout,
that doubts with double-dare!
Beware the Rubrickrant about,
the clipboard-keeper’s stare!”

He took his breadboard, voltish keen,
his gogglehood drew tight;
With pipet-lance and beaker-sheen,
he set his data right.

And while among the bustle-rows
he mulled on cause and test,
The Quibblequark, with why-ward crows,
came snicker-sneer abreast—

It flapped its maybe-maybe wings,
it mewled “But why? But why?”
It twanged the little error-strings
and poked the droppers dry.

Click-snap! went clips; the circuits chimed;
the vinegar did flare;
He timed, he tallied, trialed, and rhymed
his figures fair and square.

Thrice ran the foam; the slope held true,
the trendline would not swerve;
His tidy charts made meaning brew—
the quark lost all its nerve.

O wondrous wow! Huzza, hooray!
A ribbon kissed his board;
Through boothy bays he blazed the way,
hypothesis restored.

It beaker-hour; slicksome tubes
still whorl and wobble there;
Yet brave the minds whose curious moves
make sense from fizzing air.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about film camera in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Shutterwockery

At gloam-o'clock the silver grains
lay hush in emul-sheen;
The sprocket-teeth in winding lanes
went clitter-click between.

"Beware the Blurling-blot, my sprout,
the Hand-of-Wobble wail!
Beware the Sunflare flaring out,
the Dustmote on the veil!"

He took his clicker-kettle-box,
that leather-latched device;
Set ASA and f-number locks,
and brought the glass precise.

He stalked the skitter-lighted street,
past billboard, brick, and tin;
The Lightling made a flicker-beat
and bokehed up the din.

Ker-CLACK! the shutter spoke at last,
the mirror thrum-thrum-thrummed;
He wound the crank and, sprockets-fast,
the latent image hummed.

In bowls of midnight developer
he swirled the nightlike brew;
Stop, fix! the silver, nebular,
made secrets start to view.

He pinned it up in amber air,
the safelight softly sang;
"O flashtious day! Lensfair! Lensfair!"
The darkroom chorus rang.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on printer jam in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Jammerwog

It hummled noon; the roller-lings
Did whirr and whimple through the tray;
All crinkle-bent the paper-things,
And beepish lights went gray.

Beware the Jammerwog, my friend—
Its teeth that tug, its clamps that catch!
Beware the fuser’s scorchsome end,
The duplex gobble-latch!

He seized his nimble release-tab blade,
And tapped the spooler-queue of lore;
He waited by the breakroom shade
And eyed the toner-door.

And while in thinkish pose he leant,
The Jammerwog, with scritchy scrame,
Came fluffle-thrum from feed to vent
And gurbled jammy blame!

Clip-snap! Clip-snap! Through crumple-crease
He wrangle-wrigged his toggletine;
He teased it free; the grinding ceased—
A papery sigh, so fine.

“And hast thou tamed the Jammerwog?
Come press my hands, O tekkish friend!
O fabfous day! Clear-queue! Unclog!”
He chorkled without end.

It hummled noon; the roller-lings
Now whirr and whimple smooth alway;
No crinkle mars the paper-things—
All print their merry way.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about umbrella in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bumbershade

Drizzle-dusk, the cobble-throves
went swoggle-swish along the lane;
All flimsome lay the brimblegroves,
and mum-rills muttered rain.

“O mind the drenchling brood, my sprout—
their slap and slurp, their soppy raid!
Grip not a dream, but bring about
the brave old bumbershade.”

He popped the catch; the ribs unbent,
a spidered star of inky cloth;
Umbrella-ark, by cloudstuff lent,
to fend the weather’s froth.

Then swooped the Guzzle-Gale from north,
the Dribble-Wyrm from gutter’s side;
They sloshed and slashed and bellowed forth
their bucket-bellied tide.

Plap-plap the dropstones drumly fell;
whirl-whuff the wind-larks bayed;
But rib by rib, a stalwart shell,
he held the bumbershade.

He jabbed the squall with ferruled beak,
he turned the slathered roar;
It split to rags of spatter-squeak
and slunk to gutter-floor.

Back home he strode through glimmered mist,
his boots all puddle-proud;
“Well done, my drip-defying fist!”
the elder cried aloud.

Drizzle-ebbed, the cobble-throves
lay hush and sheen along the lane;
All glimpsy were the brimblegroves,
and far-off sang the drain.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about Monte Carlo in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Roulettiwock of Monte Carlo

’Twas glimmerhour, and the gilded palms
Did flitter-flare by Carlo’s shore;
All rubied were the roulette psalms,
While chandeliers chimed galore.

“Beware the Roulettiwock, my spry!
The whirly wheel, the house-edge bite!
Beware the banker-banders sly,
The baccarat of night!”

He gripped his vorpal betting-slip;
Long while he stalked the chancy odds;
He lounged beneath the palmshade drip
And wooed the fickle gods.

He Monte-sampled fate with dots,
With toss and toss and tally-throw;
He bootstrapped dreams in jitter-lots,
To test which way to go.

And as in sultry hush he mused,
The Roulettiwock, with velvet roar,
Came wheeling, gleamish and perfused,
And gyred across the floor.

One, two! One, two! — and snicker-stack!
His chipling hands went click and clack;
He hedged and split the emerald track,
Unspooling wheel and rack.

“And is the Roulettiwock unspun?
Come to my arms, brave chipling, come!
O lucky light! Hurray, well-won!”
He chortled, chum to chum.

’Twas glimmerhour, and the gilded palms
Did flitter-flare by Carlo’s shore;
All rubied were the roulette psalms,
While chandeliers chimed galore.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Shutterwocky

’Twas ambergloam, and silvergrains
Did whirrle-whind within the frame;
All sprocket-sleek the lensy lanes,
And safelight fog was darkroom-tame.

“Beware the Shutterwock, my child!
Its clickle-claws, its strobic glare!
Beware the Blurber, ghosting-wild,
And shun the flareish flare of flare!”

He gripped his brassbound snapper tight—
A prime-of-primes with glass galore—
Set ASA four-oh-oh for night,
And fed the teeth inside the door.

He waited where the darkslide vine
Entwines the meter’s mutter-mood;
At f/8 fate he drew a line
And listened to the city-wood.

And whilst in muffish musing stood,
The Shutterwock, with bokeh breath,
Came wiffle-whirling neonwood,
Its eyes a blinking blink of death.

He pressed release—snap-snap! ker-clap!
The curtains blinked, the gears upsprang;
Through halide seas and silver wrap
The blur-beast into stillness sprang.

“Didst net the Shutterwock?” they cried,
By dev and stop and fixer brine;
He swirled the reel with gleamish pride—
“O glare-glad hour—this frame is mine!”

’Twas ambergloam, and silvergrains
Now glitter-crisp across the frame;
All sprocket-sleek the lensy lanes—
The darkroom’s hush was safelight-tame.

prompt: Write a poem about music room in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cacophonyx in the Music-Room

Under the lamp the music-room
Went murmy in the velvet gloam;
All nimsy were the timbre-bloom,
And the tickish tempo-gnome.

“Beware the Cacophonyx, my dear!
With rattle-bite and clatter-catch!
Beware the snare-snap grizzle-gear,
And shun the rumly Ratch!”

He took his silver fiddlestick;
Long time in hush-halls wonder-wrought,
He stood beside the Measurewick
And counted beats in thought.

And as in numble note-ish muse
He leaned beside the case of ebony,
The Cacophonyx, with scrape and schooze,
Came skirling through the key.

Tick-tack! Click-clack! The bow went whack—
A sparkled brangle, fierce and spry!
He snicked it still with final crack,
And left it dumb and dry.

“And hast thou quelled the clatter-beast?
Come to my arms, my tunesome boy!
O chordful hour! O quiet feast!”
He chortle-burbled joy.

Under the lamp the music-room
Lay limny in the velvet gloam;
All flimsome were the timbre-bloom,
And meek the tempo-gnome.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Everagain

At gloam-o'-clock the swizzle groves
Skirled, swiveling round the fen;
The hush stitched hems on hollow coves—
It almost came again.

Take heed, said wind through thistle wire,
Beware the déjà-brew:
It pours the old from future fire
And ferrets sense from you.

I pocketed a loop-lit lamp,
A maybe-map with twice-born runes;
I tapped the road—tap-tap, tramp-tramp—
The dusk hummed oldish tunes.

A turning turn: the gate with scars,
The nettle-knot, the tilting yew—
O surely I had walked these bars,
O surely... had I? Who?

It sidled out, the Everagain,
A yester-when in whisk and blue;
Its eyes held hallways, stair on stair,
And said, We’ve met, we two.

I stepped aside before I stepped,
I nodded yes before I knew;
I tied the knot I’d not yet kept—
The knot untied it, too.

Round went the road; it rhymed itself,
Then tripped its tongue and split in twain;
I spoke the word upon the shelf
And heard it said again.

At gloam-o'-clock the swizzle groves
Still skirl, but soften round the fen;
The hush unhems the hollow coves—
And doesn’t come again.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about stage wings in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Whispermurk in the Stage-Wings

’Twas limmer-dim in wingéd glooms,
The gaffers gumbled under tape;
All lampish were the gobo-blooms,
And catwalks craned agape.

Mind well the flyrail’s clatter-cling,
Beware the cue-cuck clocks that peal;
Shun, shun the blackout-banshee-thing,
The Snarl of Missed Reveal!

He palmed his trusty spike-chalk stick,
His multi-multi gafferblade;
He practiced patter, nimble-quick,
And dreamed of cues well-made.

Down scrimly lanes the curtainwyrm
Came swoggle-sly with velvet breath;
Its footlights flicked in foxfire squirm,
It moulted mothy death.

“Stand by!” cried he to shadow-crew;
“Go lights!” and roll the rumble-rain!
His ghostlight, old and ever-true,
Did banish gloam and stain.

He cleft the dread with blackout fade;
The curtainwyrm uncurtained fell;
He wound its hiss in coil and braid
And stowed the tale to tell.

O stage-bright day! O cue-cascade!
Huzzinglee! Huzzanglee!
He caper-hopped across the grade
Of tape marks, proud and free.

And still the wings in limmer shade
Keep murmurmoss of scene and seam;
All lampish lie the gels we’ve laid,
The night resets its dream.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about brown butter in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Ballad of the Brownbutter

At sizzlehour the milky motes
went skirl-and-skitter in the pan;
All foamy-froth the butter floats
while poplets pattapan.

“Take heed,” crooned Gran of spatulon,
“the bronzebite comes in blinkish span;
Keep swirl and watch with steady on,
lest bitter seize the pan.”

I gripped my whirple-whisk by heft,
my maple spoon of cunning plan;
By stovewarm light I stood bereft
of all but watchful pan.

And as the hush went simmer-soft,
the foamlets thinned to chiffon flan;
Up rose a nutter-amber loft—
a hazelheart of pan.

I swirled it once, I swirled it thrice—
the milk-specks turned to caramel tan;
The room grew rich with butter-spice,
and sage leaves kissed the pan.

Then lemon-lilt went spritz-a-smile,
and hissed hello across the span;
I stayed the brink a breathless while
and tamed the bronze in pan.

We chorble-cheered, a merry brood;
the spoons went clink-a-clank began;
O nutter-gold, O sizzly mood—
we feasted from the pan.

At sizzlehour the milky motes
still skirl-and-skitter if they can;
But browned and brave the butter floats,
and all is yum in pan.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on interference in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Interfringe

At fringe-o'clock the wavy droves
did swerl and skimmer o'er the mere;
all nodish grew the borloaves,
and antinodes drew near.

"Beware the Interfere, my sprout—
its cancel-bite and phasey sneer!
Beware the crestle crashing out,
the troughling creeping near!"

He grasped his phase-blade, keen and lean—
long time he prowled the pier,
along the two-slit lanes between
the neither-far-nor-near.

He rested by a ripple stump
and hummed a hummish air,
when Interfere, with wuffle-thump,
came patterning the glare.

One—two! One—two! the phase-blade rang,
a flitter-flutter smack!
The superposed went zingle-zang;
the nodes went flicker-crack.

"Construct! Destruct!" the crests combined,
then canceled back in fear;
the Interfere was undermined
and fizzled into smear.

"And hast thou quelled the Interfere?
O fringe-bright, blessed year!
Hurroo! Hurray! Come cuddle here!"
He laughed from ear to ear.

At fringe-o'clock the wavy droves
went swerling o'er the mere;
now gentle grew the borloaves,
and antinodes made cheer.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about creep in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creeple-Creep

When glim was grim in smuddle-gloam,
And nettle-motes went snirl and steep,
Through stair and sill of hearthsome home
There sidle-sighed the Creeple-Creep.

Heed now the Creeple-Creep, my sprig—
Its sloomy tread is snudging deep;
It finds the thin between the big
And fattens slow on keep by keep.

It nibbles edge and minute-hand,
It pulls the hem of slumber’s sleeve;
It mists the maps you almost planned,
Then whistles, “Leave it—leave it—leave.”

I took my brackle-border chalk
And drew a ring, a sturdy sweep;
I set my rules in row and talk—
“No farther, O you Creeple-Creep!”

From paneled dusk and lintel-seam
It slubbered in with oozling peep—
A smear of hush, a hush of cream,
That pooled and pooled to heap on heap.

I clacked and clanged my measured sticks,
I tamped my tulps in ordered keep;
It found the gap in gaps and tricks
And threaded through me, creep by creep.

It ate the later from my now,
It stretched the maybe into deep;
It taught my promise how to bow,
And stroked my lists to lulling sleep.

So glim grows glad from smuddle-gloam,
With pockets knotted, steps I keep—
Yet under boards and breath of home
There softly hums the Creeple-Creep.
label: medium

prompt: Write a poem about awl in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Awlberdashery

In stitch-o’-time the leather lanes
went thrumble through the stall;
the pucker-winds across the grains
made whisperings to awl.

“Mind the snaggle-splinter knack,”
said Grandsire Cobb to Small;
“the scrumphish straps will skreek and crack—
so grip your prickle-awl.

Skirt buckle-bites and tackle-teeth,
and don’t let thimbles fall;
keep true your point, slip underneath,
then twist and twirl the awl.”

He tiptoed by the stropstone bright,
past pots of pitch and gall;
his thoughts went twiney, left and right,
a pilgrim with an awl.

While peering at the booted brink
where creases made a squall,
a Tangletoe began to clink—
it scuffled down the hall.

He braced his wrist; the point went in—
prik-prak, a silver spall!
Through squeal and skreek the seams grew thin;
he stitched the storm with awl.

Home by the bench, old Cobb cried out,
“O snapleaf noon! Huzoll!
Come sup and sing, you stitchers stout—
the world is mended—awl!”
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on layover bay in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Delaydrake of Layover Bay

Gloom-gilded were the sleevy coves,
and trolleys trundled rim to quay;
the gate-gulls wheeled in baggage groves
along Layover Bay.

“Mind well the Delaydrake, dear sprout—
its yawns can leach the noon to gray;
eschew the pouting Turnstile Trout
that plash at Layover Bay.”

He gripped his tag-etched stanchion-sword,
a stampy, clitter-fitted blade;
he marked the timetide, bored and bored,
and sought the driftwood shade.

And as he nursed his waiting-think,
the Delaydrake, with laggard bray,
came slumping from the check-in brink
to smutch the ticking day—

Clicker-clack! the ticket-steel
went wherrish through the yawny spray;
he snipped the net that snared the wheel
and split the beast’s delay.

He stuffed its snores in canvas sacks,
stitched minutes back to golden day;
then hoisted up his carry-brax
and left by Layover Bay.

“O gladsome hours!” the concourse sang,
“Ho, Gate A-Now and Runway K!”
He grinned, bag-bellied, bold of fang,
and strode his onward way.

Gloom-gilded were the sleevy coves—
yet spry the trolleys hummed the quay;
no Delaydrake lurks in baggage groves
about Layover Bay.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Wantway (A Desirepath Lay)

Sunslippy smirked the commons green,
The curbs held crisp decree;
Yet, shy and sly, between-betwean,
A scuffline murmured, “Me.”

“Beware the Wantway, wanderling!
Beware Desirepath’s grin!
The lure-lane crooks with beckoning—
Shun grass and keep within!”

He laced his stoutly wanderboots
Along the posted way;
He leaned beside a mumrum root
To let his thinkings sway.

And as in hushy thinkery
He knoddled chin to thumb,
Glide-wispy through the greenery
The Desirepath did come.

One-two! One-two! Through cloverblue
His footfalls whick-whack went;
He tramped a stripe, the line askew,
And skewed the sign’s intent.

“O slipglad day!” the wardens cried,
“Who scuffs our verdant toy?”
He only grinned, with grass-stains pied,
And chucklechimed with joy.

Sunslippy smirks the commons green,
The curbs still crisp decree;
But wantwise now, between-betwean,
Runs path where feet agree.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about science fair in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Datawock at the Science Fair

’Twas ohmic-eve, and slidey probes
went spin and twizzle through the gym;
The trifoldlings stood starchy-straight,
and volcanodes did brim.

“Beware the Datawock, my sprout!
Its charts that bite, its graphs that catch!
Beware false-positron about,
and shun the plagiar-snatch!”

He took his vorpal meter-stick,
his goggle-glass, his labcoat white;
He primed his lemon-cell array
and set his robot right.

And as by Ohm-oak thought he stood,
the Datawock, with stats aflare,
came whuffling from the beakerwood
and burbled, “Peer review, beware!”

Zap-zap! clip-clip! the meter-bit
went tick and tacker-tack in hand!
He trued the trends and error-slit
and felled it by the stand.

“And have you quelled the Datawock?
Come here!” cried Judgekins, bright and clear;
“O tidy trials! O error-dock!
Huzzah and hoop! All cheer!”

’Twas ohmic-eve; the slidey probes
still twizzled lightly down the aisles;
The ribbon-suns on trifold robes
made bright, awardish smiles.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Mornswoggle

At brimdawn when the milkwinds creep,
they swurl and whimple down the lane;
all hushling lie the hedgerists deep,
while dewlets bead the barley’s mane.

The Mornswoggle, with muffled tread,
goes hush-and-hither through the glen;
it drapes the roofs in drifted thread
and stills the lanes of cock and wren.

It blurms the bells, it dimples sound,
makes willows mumble, ponds go wan;
the mileposts lose their numbers round,
and footpaths dream they never ran.

I shouldered up my scarf of day,
my pockets brimming kettled heat,
and let the lanthorn sunrise sway
its honey-edges through the street.

Then see! the Mornswoggle unspools,
it rills and rilts to brook and bryn,
leaves gateposts bright as burnished tools
and leaf-lace clear on thorn and pin.

And when the brimdawn sighs once more,
the fields grow crisp, the colors right;
yet by the whisper-winding tor
it bides, to blur tomorrow’s sight.
label: medium

prompt: Create a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Conferencewocky

Mid-meeting was, the swivel-chairs
did snurdle through fluorescent gloom;
all fuddled flew the copy-airs,
and buzzle-motes bedazzed the room.

Beware the Scope-Creep, bold new hire—
it nibbles minutes, bites the day;
beware the Ladderclimb-of-Fire,
and shun the Slideserpent array.

He gripped his marker, capless, keen;
the dry-erase of sable bloom;
his laser-pointer, dotting green,
to skewer charts that fog the room.

He stalked through ficus-shadow aisles,
past carafes beading caffe-chrome;
long, long he hunted metrics-wiles,
then paused beside the hallway gnome.

And while in thinksome lull he stood,
the Meeting-Murmur, drab and dour,
came shrumbling through the cubework wood
and droned its Buzzword-Engine power.

Click-tack! Through piecharts swam and sprang
his marker with a skritch-skratch tune;
he sliced the gantts with flip and clang
and pinned the Creep against the noon.

He bagged the beast, unglazed its guff,
and left the handouts crisp with gleam;
he loped back light with victor-stuff
to cheers and claps from all the team.

Mid-meeting now, the swivel-chairs
soft snurdle in a sunnier bloom;
unfuzzled flow the copy-airs,
and nimble minds reclaim the room.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Third-Rail Hum

'Twas tunnel-tide, and rumblecars
Did joggle-jangle through the cave;
All ozonous the sparking bars,
And mumble-rails outgrave.

"Beware the Third-Rail, sprig o' mine!
The thrumming hum, the sizzle-bright!
Beware the bogie's crackle-line,
And shun its bite at night!"

He took his tester-rod in hand,
His rubber boots and visored hat;
Long while amid the sleeperland
He tarried—tunnelflat.

And, as in snuffish thought he stood,
The Third-Rail Hum, with neon mane,
Came whuffling through the tunnelwood
And crackled as it came!

Click-chunk! click-chunk! the breaker thunk—
The meter sang, "All clear! All clear!"
He dulled the zizzle's zingy funk
And hushed the humming near.

"O brabble-day! O brightish spark!"
The trackman cried, his grin aglow;
"You stilled the buzz beneath the dark—
Huzzah, my deftish Joe!"

'Twas tunnel-tide, and rumblecars
Did joggle-jangle through the cave;
All ozonous the sparking bars,
And mumble-rails behave.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on screen burn‑in in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Burn‑Inwock

’Twas pixelbrill, and glitchsome panes
Did whurl and shimmer on the screen;
All logo-lorn were status lanes,
And ghostprint bars were seen.

“Beware the Burn‑Inwock, my child!
The tickerstain! the logoscar!
Beware the oleldrift so wild,
And shun the HUD‑bar’s mar!”

He primed his calibra-sword of light,
He set the pixel-shifter’s track;
All through the savers of the night
He chased the ghosts to black.

And, in bufferish thought, he stood—
The Burn‑Inwock, with embered gaze,
Came fuzzling through the pixel‑wood
And smoldered through the haze.

Swipe-shift! Swipe-shift! The warple wipe
Went flicker-flack and tickle-tack;
He cooled the phosphors, tuned the stripe,
And smote the ghost to black.

“And hast thou foiled the Burn‑Inwock?
Come to my arms, my flicker-son!
O gladsome gleam! Hooray o’clock!
Now all the ghosts are done!”

’Twas pixelbrill, and glitchsome panes
Did whurl and shimmer on the screen;
All logo-lorn were status lanes,
And ghostprint bars were seen.

prompt: Create a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Underpass Echo

At gloam-o'clock the dripstone beams
went prinkling down the pass;
All clangled were the girded seams,
and slick the puddle-glass.

The scooters slithe, the bus-brum booms,
the pigeons flit and coo;
And under roadish, cavey rooms,
the echo doubles you.

Hark to the Underpass Echo—beware
its mimic, mummered art!
It knittles up your breath and snare
a shadow from your heart.

So take your muffle-mittens tight,
your lantern bright and brave;
And tiptoe through the flitter-light
beneath the rumble-wave.

He stepped where chalky arrows point
and coughed a "Ho!" in air;
Back "Ho! Ho!" clatterflapped the joint
from pillar, pipe, and stair.

It skreeked his words to mirror-words,
it twinned his tap and tread—
Till every bang of boot and birds
came back with doubling dread.

Then soft he shaped a whispersmall,
a gossamer hello;
It couldn't clutch the downsized call—
it tripped and lost its "oh."

He cupped the hush between his hands
and wore it like a hood;
The Echo, starved of clackish strands,
fell quiet as it could.

Outup he strode to streety light,
the drips behind were few;
The tunnel dozed in pebble-night,
its voice a drowsy blue.

At gloam-o'clock the dripstone beams
still prinkle down the pass;
But one who knows the hushful seams
can walk the puddle-glass.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about printer jam in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Jammerwock

It was spool-o’clock; the strippled reams
Did crinkle-wrinkle in their bay;
All grimsy went the feeder-beams,
And sulky rollers brayed.

“Beware the Jammerwock, my chum—
The clutch that clags, the grabbly grit!
Beware the snaggle-hinderdrum,
The frumple-tug of it!”

He took his trusty prying-pick—
The unjam-wand of office lore—
And waited by the status-click
Beside the blinking door.

And while he pondered toner-fog,
The Jammerwock, with papery jaw,
Came shrumbling through the fuser-bog
And scratched its sprockled claw.

Clip-clap! Clip-clap! Through chute and track
He flossed the folds and folded back;
He wriggled out the crumpled stack
And shut the plastic flap.

“And is the fiend made meek at last—
That creaky, clutching, grutching brute?”
He grinned: “The path runs smooth and fast;
It feeds a flawless shoot.”

O stapjous day! Caroom! Hurray!
They jigged to clicks of whirr and purr;
The Jammerwock went soft away—
A hum within a whirr.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Againling

'Twas secondeve, and loopish lanes
Did wobble-waver through the green;
So samesome lay the yester-plains,
While tick-tocks ticked unseen.

"Mind you the Againling, child of mine—
The same-toothed grin, the echo-coo;
It calls you by the olden sign
They name déjà-vu."

He gripped his Nevernewly blade,
That twicelight brand of ever-when,
And strode the rimpled, reeling shade
To meet his once-again.

Beside a roundaboutting brook
A selfsame shadow slipped the blue;
It wore a long-remembered look—
"I've met you meeting you."

Clip-clap went all the time-hinge leaves,
The world went whirr and widdershins;
He split the knot the heartbeat weaves—
Swish-swash went doubled winds.

He homeward stepped by altered lane;
His elder laughed, "Now bless the new!
You've trimmed the tether's teasing chain—
Be once, yet more than two."

'Twas secondeve, and loopish lanes
Did wobble-waver through the green;
So samesome lay the yester-plains,
While tick-tocks ticked unseen.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about music room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Cantaboggle Room

In treble-tide the hushlings hummed,
The metronooms went tick-a-tock;
All velvet were the curtains plummed,
And whispers warmed the clock.

The cellowisp and trumpetrill
Lay dozing by their stools;
The cymba-bells were patient still,
Prim-tockish, stern as schools.

He took his rosined bow in hand,
And gripped the baton-blade;
His scoreleaf shone like moonlit sand
Along the music glade.

“Mind you the Clatterflute, my sprout—
It squeals a squirmish doom;
Shun Snarlidrums that thrash about
Within the music room.”

He lingered by the pianowood
In hushish, scumble poise,
When through the stands a skirring stood—
A feral, fretty noise.

Out sprang the Screecherine on pads
Of squeaky resin-shoe;
It flailed its tongues in trills and scads,
And split the air in two.

Down beat! and up beat! presto-whirl—
He crossed its yowl with tone;
Staccabrights like sparking pearl
Ran ringing through the bone.

He folded all its squeaks to key,
And stitched the booms to bloom;
So hush became a harmony
That warmed the music room.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about layover bay in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Layover Bay

When brindleclocks blinked bide-and-stay
And gategulls flaffled o’er the bray,
The caroushells at Layover Bay
Went whirrle-whoom and waver.

The tarmaline with coffee foam
Lapped check-in rocks of telephone;
Napfish dozed in Gate-A-Drome,
While snackrels nibbled savor.

“Hark, traveler mine,” the elder spoke,
“Mind Gate-Shift’s grin and Stampit’s poke;
Shun Delay-ray’s drizzled cloak
And Standby’s snatch-and-shiver.”

He gripped his bucklebrand of pass,
His carry-on with clacking clasp;
He donned a helm of boardingglass
And paced the plushy paver.

From bin and bing the hush unlatched,
The Overbook unhooked and hatched—
The Gategrin, scannersnatch’d,
Came swarfing down the quaver.

He looped a swipe, he zagged a slice,
The bucklebrand bit thrice and twice;
The Finalcall went cold-as-ice
And fizzled into vapor.

He bore the boastful stub back home,
Past lattesea and Gate-A-Drome;
“O jingle-day, my jetty-gnome!”
They danced a caper-gavor.

Now brindleclocks blink go-and-stay,
And gategulls yawn along the bay;
All yonder hums at Layover Bay
In hush-and-shush forever.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Agenda-wock in the Conference Room

When blur-o’clock in Conference Room,
the swivel-chairs did swurl and sway;
All flimsy were the slide-deck blooms,
and the vent-ducts hummed away.

“Beware the Agenda-wock, my kin—
its buzz-breath fogs the nimble brain!
Shun Scopecreep’s gummy, grinning grin,
and stray from Drift Domain!”

He seized his dry-erase saber true;
long time the meeting-beast he sought.
He camped beside the carafe brew
and sipped the lukewarm thought.

And as he doodled action-stars
and boxed a goal or two,
the Agenda-wock with pivot-bars
came sidling into view.

Skreek-skrak! the marker sang its song;
blink-bloop! the pointer burned;
He trimmed the bullets, short and strong,
till sense alone returned.

The timer chimed; the buzz went slack;
the beast unspooled its doom.
He bagged its bloat of talking-back
and struttled from the room.

“O sprightly noon! Huzah! Huzay!”
cried all with sugared cheer;
And Conference Room grew calm and gray—
the vents just hummed, sincere.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awlkin

By cobblelight the leather loomed,
And thimble-thumps went puddle-plum;
The stitchlings skittered, needle-bloomed,
And treadles hummed a hum.

From peg to peg the Awlkin crept,
Its prickle keen as winter star;
It peeped the hide where quiet slept
And pecked a pilgrim scar.

Keep fingertips behind, I say,
For pick-peck tools are peevish spry;
They nib the night and nick the day,
They poke the world awry.

A spool of twine, a palm of cork,
He grasped the haft of oaken brown;
Through grain and grain the pointlet worked,
In whisper-pecking down.

Then threadling through the little moons
That Awlkin made in hide and heart,
He laced the gloom to golden tunes,
He stitched the seams all snug.

The boot stood brave with buttoned grin,
The satchel sang with buckles true;
The Awlkin doffed its copper pin
And slept in cedar drawers.

Now cobblelight and leather looms,
And thimble-thumps go puddle-plum;
Let Awlkin prance through prickled rooms
And treadles hum a hum.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Creepencrawl

’Twas murkling, and the glimdrab swards
Did snither-snake through dingle-keep;
All snudgy were the bramblemords,
And mumble-stalked the cunning Creep.

Mind well the Creep, my knurly kin,
The limber-lurk, the scuttle-sly;
Its velvet hush, its needled grin—
Shun shadows where its footfalls fly!

I fetched my twillish quirkle-blade,
My buckled heart in yonder glen;
I nerved my knees and candle-stayed
To wait the creepish creep again.

And as I plumped by thicket-lone,
In nither-nights and noddle-deep,
Came sizzle-soft on marrow-bone
The sidle, sidle of the Creep.

One whisker-breath, then pale and plush,
It slithered near with lizard-gleam;
I sprang—skree-skrack!—a nimble rush,
And split its hush and unseamed dream.

It fluthered out a yowlip-cry,
It twizzled twice and slumpen-slept;
I bore its hush on shoulder high,
Through smush and mire I tipple-stepped.

O gleesome-bright! O happy-croon!
Return, my brightsome sprigling, home;
Your nimble nerve, your daring boon—
Ho halladay! It quits the gloam!

’Twas murkling, and the glimdrab swards
Did snither-snake through dingle-keep;
All snudgy were the bramblemords,
And mumble-stalked the cunning Creep.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Desire-Path

’Twas gloamish on the commons wide,
The trampletufts did fray and flare;
All minksy ran the footlings’ guide,
And wishways wove the air.

“Beware the Desire-Path,” warned Gran,
“That coaxsome stripe through meadow’s mane!
Beware the hasty cut-and-span,
And shun the quick-gain lane!”

He took his gridline staff in hand;
Long while the sly-track’s lure he fought—
So perched he by the hedgerow stand
And brewed a ballast-thought.

And, as in wistful muse he stayed,
The Desire-Path, with sidle-sheen,
Came creeping through the clover-glade,
All come-and-cut-the-green!

It hummed of minutes saved in twos,
Its scuffshine slick, a ribbon lean;
It showed the soon, the slip-and-choose,
The cut across the green.

One-two! One-two! Through tuft and thyme,
His yardstick-sense went swicker-swick!
He fenced the line a second time
And cleft its cunning trick.

He tamped the sward, he sowed the seeds,
He set the posts to still the lure;
He taught the feet the chosen weaves—
A path both true and sure.

“O brightsome-brave!” old Gran did cry,
“O gleesome day of steady tread!
Come sup, my sprout, with lanterns high,
And rest your reckonèd head!”

Still gloamish on the commons wide,
Yet trampletufts grew trim and plain;
No minksy ran the wishsome guide—
The made-way held its lane.
label: high

prompt: Create a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Mufflefog

’Twas dewdim, and the muffly meads
Did murmel-mizzle down the green-lane;
All pearlwise hung the hedge-row beads,
And hushlings lulled the lane.

“Beware the Mufflefog, my sprout!
The drifts that bleer, the damp that grips!
Beware the wutherwhisp about,
The seep that sops your slips!”

He snugged his kettle-knit and cloak;
Long time he stood in smoor and stow;
So still the gate-post never spoke,
So slow the footpaths flow.

And, as in rummlish thought he stood,
The Mufflefog, with muffled tread,
Came slippling through the woolgy wood
And haloed round his head.

It swaled the thorn, it swam the heath,
It swaddled barns in feathered gray;
He tasted tin on wintered teeth
And felt the world away.

Then eastward broke a thinling beam—
A keenling, cleaving, honey-bright;
It needled seams of sodden dream
And threadled back the light.

“Oh gladsome gleam! Hooray, hooray!”
He chuckled through the chill and fog;
He warmed his hands, he found his way,
Unsworled from wisp and bog.

’Twas dayshine, and the meadow-brees
Did jingle-jangle down the plain;
All clearwise rang the hawthorn trees,
And footfalls found the lane.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about third rail hum in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Thirdrail Hum

’Twas tunnel-dark, and boggle-beams
Went shim and shamble down the grade;
All railescent the sidings gleamed,
As motor-muses played.

Beware the Thirdrail Hum, young one—
That burrow-buzz beneath the stone!
Beware the sparking shoe’s quick run,
The zizz that threads your bone!

He laced his rubber-brambled boots;
He lit an ohmish lantern-bright;
Long while he walked the sleeper routes
By greenish signal-light.

And as in subish thought he stood,
With platform-dream and ticket-crumb,
There swelled along the underwood
A low and looming Hum—

It burble-buzzed with copper breath,
It droned a dingle-dangle tone;
It whispered volts of velvet death,
It sang the steel alone.

Then cap-switch click—the breakers bit—
Tikk-takk! the traction ceased to thrum;
He tipped his cap, content a whit,
And pocketed the Hum.

“And hast thou tamed that tunnel-thing?
Come near, my brave, my ballast-son!
O railsome day! Hallooly-sing!”
He jigged for joy begun.

’Twas tunnel-dark, yet gentle beams
Went settle-soft along the grade;
All sleepity the sidings dreamed,
No rumble-stillness frayed.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on film camera in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Clickwhirr and the Silverbox

When gloamish hours unspooled the day,
light frabbled down the cobble-lane;
The leaves went sprockle-sway, and gray
came padding in on boots of rain.

“Beware the Pixel-wight, my sprout!
Beware the glow that hums too clean!
The mute-click thing that bleaches out—
shun, shun the faceless screen!”

He gripped his argent shutterbox,
the lens with bokeh-biting grin;
He wound the film with clackly knocks—
the sleepful strip asleep within.

He peered through glassy oculus,
all framelywise and breathy-slow;
The meter muttered: “Hush—and thus,”
then winked a whisper, “Now—let’s go.”

And zip! the Fleeting-Thing drew near—
the candid-blink, the once-and-gone;
It jittered on a sparrow-gear,
time’s ticklefox at dawn.

Click-clack! the shutter’s shutterwink,
the sprockets chewed a strip of night;
He netted day in silver ink
and pegged it on the perfor-line.

In redsafe hush the trays did bloom,
with devel-soup and stop-bath sting;
The emulshun woke from shadow-room,
and silver-halides learned to sing.

He tonged the neg, still dream-and-drip,
and hung the frames like moons in rows;
“O glim-bright catch! O grainy grip!”
sang heart and hosepipe hose.

And when the gloam unspools again,
go let the clickwhirr comb the air;
The snick-snap Silverbox shall pen
the light—and make it stare.
label: high
